Take heed of these <strong>expert pieces: Take heed of these expert pieces of advice regarding cover letter writing which can help you make your job application stand out.
It is essential to remember to <strong>m: It is essential to remember to maintain your focus on the needs of the company you’re applying to and the requirements and desired abilities of the ideal candidate for the role.
Each cover letter for a job application,: Each cover letter for a job application, cover letters for internships, for further study or even volunteer experience should be tailored to their specific organization and position with the pertinent keywords.
The <strong>beginning of a cover letter: The beginning of a cover letter should include a header with the candidate’s full name and contact details.
Candidates are advised and urged to do a: Candidates are advised and urged to do a little research, use their initiative and try to find the name of the person in charge of filling the new vacancy by visiting the company website and social media sites.
Towards the <strong>end of a cover lette: Towards the end of a cover letter, each candidate should write a convincing finish to entice the hiring manager and in sales terminology “seal the deal”.

Keep up to date with these expert tips s: Keep up to date with these expert tips so you can get the best out of your winning resume to ensure you get the call-back you’ve been waiting for!
It is essential for all jobseekers, whet: It is essential for all jobseekers, whether entry-level or highly experienced in their field, to construct a customized resume for each position, company or sector they apply to.
The use of <strong>KEYWORDS</strong> is: The use of KEYWORDS is often overlooked by jobseekers and they are fast becoming an integral part of a winning resume. - You can find the relevant keywords and expressions for your resume within the job vacancy, company website or profiles of other professions in that particular area.
<strong>Include the standard sections in: Include the standard sections in every resume you create - contact information, objective or summary, education, work experience and skills.
But to <strong>create a unique resume</s: But to create a unique resume that will attract a hiring manager at first glance, remember to include specific resume sections that relate to your professional profile and the vacancy on offer, such as pertinent publications, conferences you’ve attended, extra training, courses or awards you’ve received etc.
<strong>Avoid using the first person</st: Avoid using the first person: ‘I’, throughout your resume; instead always refer to the third person without using the subject. For example, in a resume objective or work experience descriptions.
<strong>Use strong verbs</strong> to des: Use strong verbs to describe your previous experience such as spearheaded, coordinated, orchestrated, established, launched, reduced (costs), increased (profits), restructured, facilitated, negotiated etc.
<strong>Demonstrate quantifiable evidenc: Demonstrate quantifiable evidence of your personal involvement in a project or impact on a role.
